Scheme 1 Synthesis of GLC from transesterification of GL with DMC. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 The proposed reaction mechanism for the synthesis of GLC from the reaction of GL with DMC by using [HPTPA]OH as a catalyst. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 The effect of reaction temperature on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction time: 90 min; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The effect of DMC/GL molar ratio on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction time: 90 min; reaction temperature: 80 °C; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The effect of reaction time on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction temperature: 80 ᵒC; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The change of the concentrations of each component in the reaction mixture with the reaction time in the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction temperature: 80 ᵒC; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 the gas chromatogram of the reaction mixture ((1) methanol, (2) DMC, (3) n-butanol, (4) DMF, (5) GD, (6) GL, (7) Tetraethylene, (8) GLC). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The effect of catalyst amount on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction temperature: 80 °C; reaction time: 90 min; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The effect of agitation speed on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction temperature: 80 ᵒC; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009; Reaction time: 90 min). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The stability of catalyst on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction temperature: 80 °C; reaction time: 90 min; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The FT-IR spectra of the fresh [HPTPA]OH and recovered [HPTPA]OH: (a) the fresh [HPTPA]OH; (b) the recovered [HPTPA]OH after the first recycle; (c) the recovered [HPTPA]OH after the third recycle (Reaction conditions: GL: 2.0 g; reaction temperature: 80 °C; reaction time: 90 min; DMC/GL molar ratio: 3; [HPTPA]OH/GL molar ratio: 0.009). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The FTIR spectra of the mixture of DMC and ILs with different contact times: (a) pure DMC; (b) DMC+[HPTPA]OH, 10 min; (c) DMC+[HPTPA]OH, 30 min; (d) DMC+[HPTPA]OH, 60 min; (e) DMC+[HPTPA]OH, 90 min; (f) DMC+[PTPA]OH, 60 min; (g) pure [HPTPA]OH. The molar ratio of DMC to ILs was set at 0.01 and the temperature is 90 °C. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 The FTIR spectra of the mixture of GL and ILs with different contact times: (a) pure GL; (b) GL+[HPTPA]OH, 10 min; (c) GL+[HPTPA]OH, 30 min; (d) GL+[HPTPA]OH, 60 min; (e) GL+[HPTPA]OH, 90 min; (f) GL+[PTPA]OH, 60 min; (g) pure [HPTPA]OH. The molar ratio of GL to ILs was set at 0.01 and the temperature is 90 °C. Fig. 11 Table 1 Catalytic performance of various catalysts a . Table 1 Entry Cat. Functionalized quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquids (FQAILs) as an economic and efficient catalyst for synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and dimethyl carbonate Elrasheed Elhaj a c Huajun Wang a b ⁎ Yanlong Gu a b ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage, Ministry of Education, Wuhan, 430074, PR China Key Laboratory for Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage Ministry of Education Wuhan 430074 PR China b Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry & Service Failure, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, PR China Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry & Service Failure School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 PR China c Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering and Technical Studies, University of Elimam Elmahdi, Kusti, P.O. School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 PR China Graphical abstract A series of functionalized quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquids (FQAILs) with different functional groups, such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, ether group, and amino, were prepared and used as a catalyst for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from transesterification of glycerol and dimethyl carbonate without any additional organic solvent and co-catalyst. The effects of functional groups, anions (Cl−, Br−, I−, OH−), and reaction parameters were investigated in detail. It is found that both the cation and anion of FQAILs display an important effect on its catalytic activity. Among these FQAILs, hydroxyl functionalized ionic liquid, [HPTPA]OH possesses the highest activity because there are the strong interactions between hydroxyl and dimethyl carbonate molecular and between anion OH− and glycerol molecular, which were shown by FTIR spectra. The glycerol conversion of 96.2% and glycerol carbonate yield of 87.6% can be obtained over [HPTPA]OH under moderate conditions of reaction temperature of 80 °C, reaction time of 90 min, dimethyl carbonate/glycerol molar ratio of 3, and catalyst amount of 0.9 mol% based on glycerol amount. The [HPTPA]OH catalyst can be reused at least three cycles without significant reduction in its catalytic activity. Finally, a possible reaction mechanism for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate is also proposed. Keywords Glycerol carbonate Ionic liquid Glycerol Transesterification Quaternary ammonium salt 1 Introduction In the last couple of decades, with the continuous reduction in fossil fuel resources and increasing concern about climate change, the production of renewable and clean fuel, such as biodiesel, has attracted much attention from the industrial and academic circles [1–4]. Generally, biodiesel is produced by transesterification of vegetable or animal oil with methanol, where the glycerol (GL) is also yielded as an undesired by-product (about 100 g/kg biodisel) [5,6]. The rapidly increase of biodiesel production has resulted in huge amounts of surplus GL and therefore, in order to promote the development of biodiesel industry, it is necessary to convert GL into value-added chemicals [7,8]. Among the derivatives of GL, glycerol carbonate (GLC) is a promising one due to its physical properties and potential uses. GLC is a nontoxic, readily biodegradable, water-soluble, not flammable (fp 165.9 °C) and viscous liquid with a very low evaporation rate (bp 353.9 °C at 101.325 kPa). All these features make GLC a green chemical that can be used as a polar high boiling solvent, a surfactant component, an intermediate for many kinds of polymers. In addition, GLC also can be utilized as components for gas separation membranes [9–13]. Several approaches have been employed for upgrading GL into GLC, including (ⅰ) the reaction of GL with phosgene [14]; (ⅱ) the direct GL carboxylation with CO2 [15–17]; (ⅲ) the carbonylation of GL with urea [18–21]; (ⅳ) the GL transesterification with dimethyl carbonate (DMC), propylene carbonate (PC), ethylene carbonate (EC), or diethyl carbonate (DEC) [22–26]. However, in these methods, the route of GL carbonation with phosgene is not suitable for the industrial production of GLC due to the highly toxic and corrosive nature of phosgene. Some catalysts, such as basic ion-exchange resin, 13X zeolite, CeO2/NbO5, and nBu2SnO were used for the direct GL carboxylation with CO2, but a very low GLC yield was obtained under harsh conditions of pressure of 5 MPa and temperature of 180 °C for this reaction is severely limited by thermodynamics [17,27]. Alternatively, carbonylation of GL with urea has better potential of commercialization. However, in this method, the removal of ammonia under reduced pressure become inevitable to drive the reaction equilibrium to the product side [28]. The transesterification of GL with ethylene carbonate or propylene carbonate was also used; however, this procedure consumed high energy for product purification because the boiling point of the by-product, ethylene glycol (bp 197 °C at 101.325 kPa) or propanediol (bp 188 °C at 101.325 kPa) is very high. Briefly, the transesterification of GL with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is the most attractive method due to the constitution of non-toxic raw material, mild operation condition, high yield, and simple purification of GLC, which collectively offers an environmentally benign route for synthesizing GLC (Scheme 1 ) [29]. Up to now, a series of catalysts were developed to catalyze the reaction of GL with DMC. The homogeneous catalysts, such as K2CO3, NaOH, and KOH, showed high catalytic activity [30]. However, it was difficult to separate and reuse these catalysts. The heterogeneous catalysts, such as metal salts or oxides (CaO, KNO3/CaO, K2CO3/MgO, Mg1+xCa1-xO2, MgO-La2O3, Li-La2O3), hydrotalcite (LDHx, HT-M), Na-Based Zeolite, and so on [31–34], were also discovered to possess high activities for the transesterification of GL with DMC to produce GLC. However, some drawbacks are associated with heterogeneous catalyst, including easily deactivation, leaching of catalyst active sites, and large energy consumption due to calcination step needed in their preparation and regeneration process. Several lipases, like Novozym 435 and Aspergillus niger, were also used as heterogeneous catalyst for the reaction of GL with DMC [35,36]. Unfortunately, these catalysts are suffering many drawbacks, such as high cost, poor activity, large DMC/GL molar ratio, and long reaction time (˜25 h). In addition, some solvents, such as THF (tetrahydrofuran) and DMF (dimethyl formamide), are often added in the reaction system to overcome the resistance of mass transfer due to the insolubility of GL with DMC, which further make it difficult to purify the product [29]. Ionic liquid (IL) is a kind of new solvent and catalyst with many unique properties, such as negligible vapor pressure, good thermal stability, excellent tunability, and high solubility [37]. Furthermore, it is easy to adjust IL’s acid-base property by changing its cation-anion pairing. These properties make the IL widely available as a catalyst for cycloaddition of propylene oxide with CO2, Knoevenagal-Michael reaction, direct aldol reactions, aza-Michael reaction and so on [38–40]. Meanwhile, its dual function, namely strong solubility and catalytic activity, often results in an increase in rate and reactivity for the transesterification reaction, compared with other catalysts that need additional solvent to overcome the resistance of mass transfer. In addition, some basic groups, such as hydroxyl (−OH), carboxyl (−COOH), and amino (-NH2), can be easily attached on the alkyl arms of ILs to produce functionalized ILs, which reflect additional advantages such as alterable polarity, low viscosity, higher solubility, and immobilization potential [41,42]. Compared with imidazole ILs, quaternary ammonium salts ILs are more suitable catalyst in industrial processes owing to simpler preparation process, cheaper cost, and less toxicity. To the best of our knowledge, there are few reports about the synthesis of GLC form GL and DMC by using functionalized quaternary ammonium salts ILs (FQAILs) as a catalyst. Moreover, the role of both functional group and anion of the ILs for activation of the reactant molecules in the GLC synthesis process is also not understood clearly. In the present work, a series of FQAILs with different functional groups, such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, ether group, and amino, were prepared and then used as a catalyst for the synthesis of GLC from transesterification of GL and DMC without any additional organic solvent or co-catalyst. The effects of cations, anions (Cl−, Br−, I−, OH−), and reaction parameterswere also investigated in detail. Finally, based on the current results and FTIR characterization, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed for the synthesis of GLC. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Tripentylamine (TPA) (97%), 3-bromo-1-propanol (97%), methyl-4-bromobutanoate (98%), 1-methylimidazole (99%), 3-chloropropionic acid (98%), 1-bromopropane (99%), GL (99%), glycidol (GD) (97%), and GLC (90%) were purchased from Shanghai SaEn Chemical Technology Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. 3-Bromopropylamine hydrobromide (98%) and 1-bromo-3-methoxypropane (98%) were provided by Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Tetraethylene glycol (99%) and DMC (99%) were provided by Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute, China. Methanol and n-butanol with 99% purity were purchased from Shanghai Zhan Yun Chemical Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. The DMF, THF, anhydrous diethyl ether, and ethanol solvents have purity of 99%. 2.2 Preparation of FQAILs The FQAILs were prepared according to the previous methods [41,42] and the TPA was used as starting materials. In a typical procedure for the preparation of Hydroxypropyl-tripentylammonium hydroxide ([HPTPA]OH), 4.55 g of TPA (20 mmol) and 45 mL of THF were firstly mixed in a round bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser, and then, 2.77 g of 3-bromo-1-propanol (20 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture. After stirred at 80 °C for 24 h with protection of nitrogen current, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. The resulting reaction mixture became two phases and the yellow viscous liquid was obtained by removing the solvent phase. The yellow viscous liquid was further washed with anhydrous diethyl ether three times (20 mL × 3) to remove any impurities. The resulting yellow concentrated liquid was dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 18 h, providing Hydroxypropyl-tripentylammonium bromide ([HPTPA]Br). Then, 3.31 g of [HPTPA]Br (0.01 mol) was added into the solution of KOH (0.85 g, 0.015 mol) in ethanol (35 mL), and the resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h to complete the anion exchange process. During the process, the KBr white precipitate was formed and then removed by filtration. After concentrating the filtrate by removing the solvent and impurities, 2.74 g of clear yellow liquid was obtained. Then it was further dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 18 h to give [HPTPA]OH. Aminopropyl-tripentylammonium hydroxide ([APTPA]OH), Methoxypropyl-tripentylammonium hydroxide ([MPTPA]OH), Tripentylammonium hydroxide ([TPA]OH), and Propyl-tripentylammonium Hydroxide ([PTPA]OH) were prepared by the same process with [HPTPA]OH using 3-bromopropylamine hydrobromide, 1-bromo-3-methoxypropane, hydrobromic acid, and 1-bromopropane instead of 3-bromo-1-propanol, respectively. The same process with [HPTPA]OH was also used to prepare 1-Hydroxypropyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide ([HPMIM]OH) by using 1-methylimidazole instead of TPA. Hydroxypropyl-tripentylammonium chloride ([HPTPA]Cl) was prepared by the reaction of [HPTPA]OH with hydrochloric acid while Hydroxypropyl-tripentylammonium iodide ([HPTPA]I) was prepared by the reaction of [HPTPA]OH with hydroiodic acid. Carboxypropyl-tripentylammonium hydroxide ([CPTPA]OH) was prepared by the following procedure: 4.55 g of TPA (20 mmol) was mixed with 3.65 g of methyl-4-bromobutanoate (20 mmol) in a round bottom flask, and then 30 mL of THF was added to the mixture. After stirred at 80 °C for 24 h with protection of nitrogen current, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the yellow viscous liquid was obtained by removing the solvent phase. The yellow viscous liquid was further washed with anhydrous diethyl ether three times (20 mL × 3) to remove any impurities and then mixed with 50 mL of hydrobromic acid (0.03 mol/L). After stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h, the yellow liquid, carboxypropyl-tripentylammonium bromide ([CPTPA]Br) was obtained by removing the solvent. Finally, the [CPTPA]OH was obtained by the reaction of [CPTPA]Br with KOH. 2.3 FQAILs characterization All the FQAILs catalysts were characterized by the nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). The 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Advance 400 MHz spectrometer. The results are listed as following: [HPTPA]OH: yellow liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 3.66 – 3.16 (m, 8 H), 2.95 – 2.30 (m, 7H), 2.10 (t, J = 6.2 HZ, 1H), 1.10–1.60 (m, 7H), 1.50 – 1.40 (m, 10H), 1.02 – 1.00 ppm (m, 8H). [CPTPA]OH: yellow liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 3.20 – 2.30 (m, 5H), 2.44 – 2.41 (m, 15 H), 1.80 – 1.64 (m, 6H), 1.42 – 1.31 (m, 8H), 1.00 – 0.93 ppm (m, 7H). [APTPA]OH: yellow viscous liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 2.43 – 2.40 (m, 7 H), 1.50 – 1.40 (m, 7 H), 1.34 – 1.26 (m, 11 H), 0.92 – 0.90 (m, 13 H). [MPTPA]OH: yellow viscous liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 3.42 - 3.33 (m, 2 H), 2.50 – 2.30 (m, 7 H). 1.74 – 1.70 (m, 1 H) 1.50 – 1.40 (m, 6 H), 1.34 – 1.24 (m, 13 H), 0.91 – 0.84 (m, 12 H). [TPA]OH: colorless liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 2.41 – 2.30 (m, 5 H), 2.20 – 2.02 (m, 1 H), 1.50 – 1.40 (m, 6 H), 1.30 – 1.24 (m, 9 H), 1.05 – 0.84 (m, 11 H). [PTPA]OH: colorless liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 2.70 – 2.32 (m, 7 H), 1.60 – 1.50 (m, 6 H), 1.40–1.60 (m, 14 H), 0.91 – 0.90 (m, 12). [HPTPA]Cl: yellow liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 3.83 – 3.40 (m, 5 H), 3.21 – 3.20 (m, 8 H), 2.60 – 2.40 (m, 1 H), 2.02 – 1.60 (m, 7 H), 1.40 – 1.13 (m, 8 H), 1.00 – 0.80 (m, 7 H). [HPTPA]Br: yellow liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3Cl3, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 3.84 – 3.51 (m, 4 H), 3.30 – 2.30 (m, 9 H), 2.12 – 1.60 (m, 8 H), 1.40 – 1.11 (m, 10 H), 1.10 – 0.92 (m, 9 H). [HPTPA]I: yellow viscous liquid, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C, TMS): δ = 3.82 – 3.20 (m, 13 H), 2.40 – 2.36 (m, 1 H), 2.02 – 1.55 (m, 8 H), 1.40 – 1.20 (m, 8 H), 1.00 – 0.91 (m, 8 H). A Bruker VERTEX 70 FT-IR spectrometer was used to obtain the FT-IR spectra of samples with 2 cm−1 resolution over the wavenumber range 4000-400 cm−1. 2.4 Reaction procedure The synthesis of GLC from the reaction of GL with DMC by using FQAILs as catalysts was carried out in a 50 mL round bottom 3-neck glass flask as a batch reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a thermometer, and a reflux condenser. The energy was applied to the glass flask with a constant temperature oil bath. The accuracy of the temperature measurements was ± 0.5 °C. The reflux condenser, which was a straight condenser tube with the tap water as the cooling medium, can cool all the volatiles and return them into the glass flask to keep the material balance of the reaction. In a typical run, 21.70 mmol of GL (2.0 g) and 43.40 mmol of DMC (3.91 g) were mixed in the flask, and then 0.20 mmol [HPTPA]OH was loaded into the mixture, which was quickly heated to 80 °C and kept for 90 min with a stirring speed of 300 rpm. After that, the reaction mixture was cooled to the room temperature. In order to recover the catalyst, 15.0 mL of anhydrous diethyl ether was added into the reaction mixture to make two phases. The upper phase (product phase) consists of the product, the residual reactants, and anhydrous diethyl ether, while the lower phase (catalyst phase) mainly consists of the catalyst. After the two phases were separated by separating funnel, the upper phase was sampled to analyze while the lower phase was evaporated by rotary evaporator to further purify the catalyst. The recovery catalyst was dried in a vacuum drier at 60 °C and 24 h and then used in the recycled experiment. 2.5 Product analysis The sample was taken from the cooled reaction mixture and diluted with a certain amount of DMF, and then analyzed by the gas chromatography (Fuli 9790-II) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column DM-FFAP (30 m long, 0.25 mm i.d). As an internal standard, n-Butanol was used to determine GD, methanol, and DMC while tetraethylene glycol was used to determine GL and GLC. Nitrogen (99.999% pure) was used as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 0.3 MPa. The injector and detector temperatures were 250 °C and 270 °C, respectively. The temperature of the column was programmed as follows: 2 min initial hold at 70 °C, 15 °C/min ramp from 70 °C to 250 °C, and then 15 min hold at 250 °C A good peak separation was achieved for all components in the sample at these conditions. The conversion of GL, XGL , the yield of GLC, YGLC , and the yield of GD, YGD , were calculated by using Eqs. (1)–(3), respectively, while the selectivity of GLC, SGLC , was calculated by Eq. (4): (1) X G L = n G L i n − n G L o u t n G L i n × 100 % (2) Y G L C = n G L C o u t n G L i n × 100 % (3) Y G D = n G D o u t n G L i n × 100 % (4) S G L C = n G L C o u t n G L i n − n G L o u t × 100 % where, n G L i n is the initial mole number (mol) of GL while n G L o u t , n G L C o u t , and n G D o u t are the mole numbers (mol) of GL, GLC, and GD in the residual reaction mixture after the reaction, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of various catalysts Table 1 shows the catalytic performance of various FQAILs catalysts with hydroxyl, carboxyl, amino, and ether group (entry 1 ˜ 4), TPA (entry 5), and the traditional quaternary ammonium salts ILs without any functional group, such as [TPA]OH and [PTPA]OH (entry 6, 7), for the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC. It is found that the organic base TPA catalyst has a lower catalytic activity whereas the FQAILs catalysts display higher catalytic activities than TPA (entry 1 ˜ 4, 5). Meanwhile, traditional quaternary ammonium salts ILs without any functional group, such as [TPA]OH and [PTPA]OH, also exhibit lower catalytic activities than FQAILs (entry 1 ˜ 4, 6, 7). The results indicate that the functional groups play an important role in the acceleration of the reaction of GL with DMC. It is also discovered that the activity order of FQAILs is [HPTPA]OH > [CPTPA]OH > [APTPA]OH > [MPTPA]OH, which means that the activities of the four functional groups are increased based on the following order: −OH > −COOH > -NH2 > -O-. Recently, it was reported that hydroxyl-functionalized quaternary ammonium hydroxide ILs displayed a good catalytic activity for synthesis of DMC from methanol and carbon dioxide due to the generation of hydrogen bond between hydroxyl oxygen atom and the hydrogen atom of methanol molecule and between hydroxyl hydrogen atom and oxygen atom of carbon dioxide molecule [41,42]. The result suggests that during the reaction of GL with DMC over [HPTPA]OH, the hydrogen bond is generated between hydroxyl oxygen atom and the hydrogen atom of GL molecule and between hydroxyl hydrogen atom and carboxyl oxygen atom of DMC molecule, which is beneficial for the activation of GL molecule and DMC molecular. In addition, the reason of [HPTPA]OH possesses the highest catalytic activity between the four FQAILs (entry 1 ˜ 4) may be due to the strength of hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl of [HPTPA]OH and DMC. The traditional quaternary ammonium salts ILs, such as [TPA]OH and [PTPA]OH, exhibit higher catalytic activity than TPA, indicting the positive role of the basic anion OH− in this reaction. In order to determine the anion effects, the hydroxyl-functionalized quaternary ammonium salt ILs with different anions, such as OH−, Cl−, Br−, and I−, were prepared and used to catalyze the reaction of GL with DMC (entry 1, 9˜11). It is observed that for the four FQAILs with different anions, the GLC yield increase in the following order: OH− > Cl− > Br− > I−, which is consistent with the order of the basic strength of anion. During the reaction of GL with DMC, the OH− as a strong Brønsted base has the strongest proton accepting ability and the GL is easily activated to form the glyceroxide. In addition, it also can be found that the [PTPA]OH without hydroxyl has a lower catalytic activity than [HPTPA]OH, while [HPTPA]Cl, [HPTPA]Br, or [HPTPA]I without anion OH− also displays a lower catalytic activity than [HPTPA]OH. This result suggests that there may be a synergic effect between cation with hydroxyl and anion OH−, which results in a good catalytic activity of [HPTPA]OH for the reaction of GL with DMC [43]. In addition, the hydroxyl functionalized imidazolium salt ILs [HPMIM]OH was also prepared and used to catalyze the reaction of GL with DMC. The result indicates that the GL conversion and GLC yield are 89.5% and 49.5%, respectively, for [HPMIM]OH (entry 8), which are less than that for [HPTPA]OH. Furthermore, the GLC selectivities for [HPMIM]OH and other FQAILs, such as [CPTPA]OH, [APTPA]OH, and [HPTPA]Br are also less than that for [HPTPA]OH. For all the catalysts, the by-product is GD, which is produced by the decarboxylation of GLC. The above results indicate that among these catalysts, the highest GL conversion and GLC yield and higher GLC selectivity are obtained over [HPTPA]OH. Accordingly, in this study, the [HPTPA]OH is used as a catalyst to investigate the effects of other reaction parameters, such as reaction temperature, DMC/GL molar ratio, reaction time, and catalyst amount. 3.2 Optimization of reaction conditions 3.2.1 Effect of reaction temperature Fig. 1 shows the effect of reaction temperature on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC by using [HPTPA]OH as a catalyst. When the reaction temperature increases from 60 °C to 80 °C, the GL conversion and GLC yield increase rapidly from 41.5% and 39.8% to 96.0% and 86.6% at 75 °C and then at 80 °C slightly increase to 96.2% and 87.6%, respectively. Meanwhile, the GD yield increases from 1.7% at 60 °C to 15.8% at 70 °C and then decreases to 8.5% at 80 °C. Because the transesterification of GL with DMC is an exothermic reaction [44], the high reaction temperature can shift the reaction equilibrium towards product side. Hence, the temperature of 80 °C is suitable for the reaction of GL with DMC to produce GLC. 3.2.2 Effect of DMC/GL molar ratio The effect of DMC/GL molar ratio on the transesterification of GL with DMC to produce GLC in the presence of [HPTPA]OH as a catalyst was investigated and the result is listed in Fig. 2 . The results demonstrate that when the DMC/GL molar ratio is increased from 1 to 2, the GL conversion and GLC yield increase remarkably from 52.0% and 19.7% to 91.3% and 82.7%, respectively. With the further increase of DMC/GL molar ratio to 5, the GL conversion is increased to 94.9% while the GLC yield decreases from 94.8% at DMC/GL molar ratio of 4 to 90.1%. In addition, with the increase of DMC/GL molar ratio from 1 to 5, the GD yield gradually decreases from 32.4% to 4.8%. Due to the short reaction time of 90 min, except GD, any other byproduct is not detected in the reaction mixture. These results indicate that the higher DMC/GL molar ratio rather than stoichiometric ratio is required to optimize the GLC synthesis since the reaction of GL with DMC is a reversible one. Hence, the DMC/GL molar ratio of 3 or 4 can be suitable for the reaction of GL with DMC. 3.2.3 Effect of reaction time The effect of reaction time on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC was also scrutinized. As shown in Fig. 3 , at the initial 20 min, the reaction of GL with DMC proceeds very quickly and gives the GL conversion of 74.0% and GLC yield of 64.2%. As the reaction time increases to 40 min, the reaction rate decreases slightly and the GL conversion and GLC yield increase to 93.5% and 77.2%, respectively. Further increase in the reaction time to 180 min increases the ratio of conversion of GL (96.2%) and yield of GLC (87.6%) at 90 min, and then the GL conversion and GLC yield remain constant with the reaction time. Meanwhile, the GD yield increases to 16.2% at 40 min and then slowly decreases to 11.3% at 180 min. Therefore, the reaction time of 60 ˜ 90 min is suitable for the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC. The Fig. 4 illustrates the change of concentrations of each component in the reaction mixture with the reaction time. It can be observed that during the reaction process, the reactants, GL and DMC are consumed gradually while the product, GLC is generated continually with the time. Moreover, the methanol is also produced during the reaction, as a by-product. The Fig. 5 is the gas chromatogram of the reaction mixture. It can be seen that a good peak separation is achieved for all the components. In addition, the carbon balance of the reaction process is 97.4% indicating the reliability of the results. 3.2.4 Effect of catalyst amount The effect of the catalyst amount on the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC with [HPTPA]OH as a catalyst is presented in Fig. 6 . It can be observed that with the increase of catalyst amount from 0.3 mol% to 1.5 mol% (based on GL), the GL conversion and GLC yield further increase from 92.2% and 81.8% to 96.2% and 87.6%, respectively, at catalyst amount of 0.9 mol%, and then, they almost keep constants with catalyst amount. Meanwhile, the GD yield decreases slowly from 10.4% to 7.0% with increase of catalyst amount. Considering that the less amount of catalyst is better for the industrial production of GLC, hence, the catalyst amount of 0.9 mol% is suitable for the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC. 3.2.5 Effect of agitation speed In the previous studies [33,36], it was found that when the traditional catalysts, such as K2CO3 and lipases, were used for the reaction, there are two liquid phases in the reaction mixture at the initial reaction stage due to the limited miscibility of GL with DMC and lower GL conversion [11]. Therefore, the solvents, such as THF, are often added in the reaction system to overcome the resistance of mass transfer, which further increases the difficulty of purifying the product. However, when the [HPTPA]OH is used as a catalyst for the reaction of GL with DMC, the miscibility of GL with DMC will be improved because the GL can be completely dissolved in [HPTPA]OH IL while the DMC can be partially dissolved in IL. It means that at the initial reaction stage, the resistance of mass transfer in the reaction mixture for [HPTPA]OH is less than that for traditional catalyst because [HPTPA]OH not only has higher catalytic activity, but also has stronger solubility for GL and DMC. Though the limited miscibility of GL with DMC is not beneficial for the reaction, the mass transfer may have no larger negative effect on the catalytic performance of [HPTPA]OH. Compared with other catalysts that need an additional solvent to overcome the resistance of mass transfer, the [HPTPA]OH presents a remarkable advantage owing to its strong solubility. The resistance of mass transfer can be further decreased by increasing the agitation speed. The effect of agitation speed on the reaction performance has been studied and the results are given in Fig. 7 . It can be found that when the agitation speed increases from zero to 300 rpm, the GL conversion and GLC yield increase from 82.5% and 70.8% to 96.2% and 87.6%, respectively. These results indicate that a high agitation speed can improve the diffusion of reactant molecules resulting in an increase of reaction rate and GL conversion. With further increase of agitation speed to 500 rpm, the GL conversion and GLC yield almost keep constant. Hence, the agitation speed of 300 rpm is suitable for the reaction of GL with DMC. 3.2.6 Stability of catalyst In order to investigate the stability of [HPTPA]OH catalyst, recycling experiments were also carried out. Firstly, the catalyst was separated by extraction method with anhydrous diethyl ether. Then, after dried in a vacuum dryer, the recovered catalyst was reused for the next run under the same conditions. As shown in Fig. 8 , at the third recycle, the GL conversion and the GLC yield still can reach 92.6% and 80.9%, respectively, over the recovered catalyst. However, at the forth recycle, the GL conversion and GLC yield decrease to 63.0% and 57.8%, respectively, for recovered [HPTPA]OH catalyst. This result indicates that the [HPTPA]OH can be reused efficiently at least for three times. In the above recycling experiments, the catalyst was recovered by adding anhydrous diethyl ether into the reaction mixture to make two phases: product phase and catalyst phase. The catalyst [HPTPA]OH is concentrated in the catalyst phase while the product phase consists of unreacted GL, excess DMC, GLC, GD and methanol. In order to determine whether any catalyst still remain in the product phase and are not recovered completely, another 15.0 mL of anhydrous diethyl ether was again added into the product phase. If there are some catalysts in the product phase, it will be separated out. However, the result indicates when the anhydrous diethyl ether was added into the product phase, only a very little of catalyst were separated from the product phase, reflecting that the amount of [HPTPA]OH remained in product phase is very small and most of the IL catalysts can be recovered by adding the anhydrous diethyl ether into the reaction mixture. The fresh [HPTPA]OH, the recovered [HPTPA]OH after the first recycle, and the recovered [HPTPA]OH after the third recycle are characterized by FTIR and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . In these spectra in the Fig. 9, the wide band at about 3388 cm−1 are assigned to the −OH stretching vibration while the band at 1063 cm−1 are attributed to the C–N stretching vibration. In addition, the peaks at 2940 cm−1, 2869 cm−1, and 1664 cm−1 suggest the presence of ammonium salt. After the third recycle, it can be observed that these characteristic band are also strong almost without any significant shift of the absorption frequency (Fig. 8(c)), indicating the [HPTPA]OH has strong structure stability during the reaction process. According to these results, it can be inferred that the important reason for the deactivation of [HPTPA]OH is the loss of the catalyst during the experiment process because the amount of the recovered catalyst is decreased after every recycle experiment, especially after the fifth recycle. 3.3 Synthesis of GLC from GL and other organic carbonates over [HPTPA]OH The above results indicate that the [HPTPA]OH is an effective catalyst for the synthesis of GLC from GL and DMC. In order to investigate the applicability of [HPTPA]OH to other organic carbonates, the transesterification of GL with other organic carbonates, such as DEC, PC, and EC to produce GLC was also examined and the results are listed in Table 2 (in row 1 ˜ 3). It can be found that the [HPTPA]OH also exhibits considerable activity for these carbonates. The highest GL conversion (97.9%) was obtained for EC as the substrate while the highest GLC yield of 79.4% was obtained for DEC. When PC was used as reactant, the GL conversion and GLC yield can reach 85.4% and 75.5%, respectively, in the presence of [HPTPA]OH. The catalytic activities of the other molecular catalysts for GLC synthesis from GL and these different organic carbonates are also showed in Table 2 (in row 4 ˜7). It can be found that the [HPTPA]OH has a slightly lower GLC yield than MgO, CaO, 1,3-Dichlorodistannoxanes, and Ca-HT catalysts. However, compared with these catalysts, the [HPTPA]OH possesses a higher turnover frequencies (TOFs) (except 1,3-Dichlorodistannoxanes). These results indicate that the highly efficient of [HPTPA]OH can be extended to a variety of organic carbonates to produce to GLC. 3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism There are few reports on the role of both cation and anion of the ILs for activation of the substrates in the GLC synthesis process. In order to clearly understand the reaction mechanism of GL with DMC in the presence of [HPTPA]OH, the FTIR spectra are used to characterize the interaction between [HPTPA]OH and DMC and between [HPTPA]OH and GL. The results are illustrated in Figs. 10 and 11 . In Fig. 10(a), the peak at 1762 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of CO of DMC, which shifts to the lower frequency of 1753 cm−1 when DMC is mixed with [HPTPA]OH (Fig. 10(b–d)). Furthermore, the strength of peak of CO decreases with the increase of contact time (except Fig. 10 (e)). It indicates that there is a interaction between CO of DMC and [HPTPA]OH. However, as the DMC is mixed with [PTPA]OH, the peak of CO do not shift to the low frequency, meaning there is no interaction between CO and [PTPA]OH. Therefore, the results indicate that the CO of DMC prefer to interacting with hydroxyl group of cation rather than with anion OH-. Based on the report in literature [38–40], we believe that the interaction of CO of DMC with hydroxyl group of cation is due to the formation of hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom of CO and the hydrogen atom of hydroxyl, which will result in the activation of DMC molecular. By the same token, in Fig. 11(a), the absorption band centered at 3462 cm−1 corresponding to the hydroxyl group of GL shifts to the lower frequency of 3367 cm−1 when GL is contacted with [HPTPA]OH (Fig. 11(b–d)), indicating that there is a interaction between hydroxyl group of GL and [HPTPA]OH. Meanwhile, the shifting of peak of hydroxyl group of GL to low frequency also occurs in the mixture of GL and [PTPA]OH (Fig. 11 (e)), meaning that there also is a interaction between hydroxyl group of GL and [PTPA]OH. These results suggest that the interaction of hydroxyl group of GL with [HPTPA]OH is produced between hydroxyl group of GL and anion OH- of [HPTPA]OH with the formation of hydrogen bond between the hydrogen atom of hydroxyl group of GL and oxygen atom of anion OH- [38,39]. The above FTIR spectra results clearly indicate that during the reaction of GL with DMC in the presence of [HPTPA]OH, the two kinds of hydrogen bonds are formed between hydrogen atom of hydroxyl group of GL and anion OH- of [HPTPA]OH and between carbonyl oxygen atom of DMC and hydroxyl hydrogen atom of cation, resulting in the activation of GL and DMC to initiate the reaction. These results further prove there is a synergic effect between anion and cation of [HPTPA]OH for the synthesis of GLC. Based on the results of experiments and characterization of [HPTPA]OH, a possible reaction mechanism for the GLC synthesis from GL and DMC is proposed as shown in Scheme 2 . During the reaction, firstly, the CO bond of DMC and the primary OH bond of GL can be activated by the hydroxyl of cation and the OH− anion of [HPTPA]OH, respectively, resulting in a active state of DMC and GL with the formation of (OH…O) hydrogen bond and (HO⋯H) hydrogen bond. Afterwards, activated GL makes nucleophilic attack to the carbonyl-carbon atom of DMC to form a methyl glyceryl carbonate intermediate with elimination of methoxy group in the form of methanol. Subsequently, the secondary OH bond of GL is also activated by the OH− anion of the [HPTPA]OH with the formation of the (HO⋯H) hydrogen bond and then its oxygen atom makes an intramolecular nucleophilic attack on carbonyl carbon atom to give GLC with a loss of another molecule of methanol. 3.5 Comparison of the catalytic activity between different catalysts The comparison of the catalytic activity of [HPTPA]OH with other ILs catalysts for GLC synthesis is listed in Table 3 (in row 1 ˜ 14). Although the different reaction conditions were used for these catalysts, these reaction conditions should be the optimized one for each catalyst. So the catalytic activities of these catalysts can be compared by using the GLC yields at these optimal conditions. It is found that the catalytic activity of [HPTPA]OH is slightly higher than that of TBA-MCM41, DABCO-DMC, [TMG]TFE, [TMA]OH, [TEA]OH, and [TBA]OH. Meanwhile, it is also discovered that though the catalysts, such as Emim[Ac], Dicyanamide, Triethylamine, TBAB, DBU, [Bmin]Im, and BMIM-2−CO2, gave higher GLC yields than [HPTPA]OH, these catalysts were used at higher reaction temperature, or at longer reaction time, or at larger DMC/GL molar ratio, or at larger catalyst amount than [HPTPA]OH. In addition, the TOFs of these catalysts also are listed in Table 3 (in eighth column). It is also noticed that the TOF of [HPTPA]OH is higher than of Dicyanamide, Triethylamine, TBAB, DABCO-DMC, [Bmin]Im, and BMIM-2−CO2. Furthermore, the catalytic activities of other non-ILs catalysts for GLC synthesis from GL and DMC are also showed in Table 3 (in row 15 ˜ 31). It is found that the TOF of [HPTPA]OH is also higher than that of these non-ILs catalysts (except CaCO3). Compared with these catalysts, the [HPTPA]OH can give higher GLC yield of 87.6% under milder conditions: reaction temperature of 80 °C, 1.5 h, DMC/GL molar ratio of 3, and catalyst amount of 0.9 mol% (based on GL). Furthermore, as a FQAIL, [HPTPA]OH has simpler prepared process, cheaper cost, less toxicity as well as higher activity and thereby, it may be as a alternative active component of industrial catalyst for GLC synthesis. 4 Conclusion Several FQAILs show excellent catalytic activities for GLC synthesis from GL and DMC. The activity of functional groups in this study increase in the following order: −OH > −COOH > -NH2 > -O-, which may be relative with the strength of their hydrogen bonds with DMC, while the anions show the following activity order: OH− > Cl− > Br− > I−, which is consistent with their basic strength. Among these catalysts, the [HPTPA]OH with hydroxyl and anion OH− gives the highest catalytic activity. FTIR characterization clearly shows there are the strong interactions between hydroxyl and dimethyl carbonate molecular and between anion OH- and glycerol molecular. Under the mild reaction conditions of reaction temperature of 80 °C, 90 min, DMC/GL molar ratio of 3, and catalyst amount of 0.9 mol% (based on GL), the GL conversion and GLC yield can respectively reach 96.2% and 87.6% over [HPTPA]OH catalyst. The high efficiency of [HPTPA]OH can be extended to other organic carbonates for the synthesis of GLC. This catalyst can be easily recovered and reused and may be used as an alternative active component for industrial process. A possible reaction mechanism for GLC synthesis from GL and DMC is also proposed. coredata.dc:description: A series of functionalized quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquids (FQAILs) with different functional groups, such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, ether group, and amino, were prepared and used as a catalyst for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from transesterification of glycerol and dimethyl carbonate without any additional organic solvent and co-catalyst. The effects of functional groups, anions (Cl−, Br−, I−, OH−), and reaction parameters were investigated in detail. It is found that both the cation and anion of FQAILs display an important effect on its catalytic activity. Among these FQAILs, hydroxyl functionalized ionic liquid, [HPTPA]OH possesses the highest activity because there are the strong interactions between hydroxyl and dimethyl carbonate molecular and between anion OH− and glycerol molecular, which were shown by FTIR spectra. The glycerol conversion of 96.2% and glycerol carbonate yield of 87.6% can be obtained over [HPTPA]OH under moderate conditions of reaction temperature of 80 °C, reaction time of 90 min, dimethyl carbonate/glycerol molar ratio of 3, and catalyst amount of 0.9 mol% based on glycerol amount. The [HPTPA]OH catalyst can be reused at least three cycles without significant reduction in its catalytic activity. Finally, a possible reaction mechanism for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate is also proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Functionalized quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquids (FQAILs) as an economic and efficient catalyst for synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and dimethyl carbonate
